item.title: Causes and Treatment of Diarrhea: What You Need to Know
item.dc:creator: diggusa
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever had an upset stomach that just won't quit? You know, the kind where you're running to the bathroom every few minutes and hoping the rolls of toilet paper don't run out. If so, you've probably experienced diarrhea. Diarrhea, also known as the "runs," is having loose and watery stools at least three times a day. It's usually caused by a viral infection and lasts a few days, but can lead to dehydration if you're not careful. The good news is there are some simple steps you can take to get your digestive system back on track. Keep reading to learn what may have caused your frequent trips to the porcelain throne and how to put a stop to them.

Common Causes of Diarrhea

Diarrhea can be caused by a number of factors, including:
  • Bacterial or viral infections. The stomach flu virus and food poisoning are common culprits, leading to diarrhea that lasts 1-2 days. See a doctor if it persists or is accompanied by severe pain, dehydration, or bloody stools.
  • Food intolerances or allergies. For some people, dairy, high-fat or highly spicy foods can trigger diarrhea. Eliminate suspected foods from your diet to determine the cause.
  • Medications. Antibiotics, blood pressure medications, and NSAIDs like ibuprofen can sometimes lead to diarrhea as a side effect. Talk to your doctor about alternatives or dosage adjustments.
  • Digestive issues. Conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), ulcerative colitis, and Crohn's disease can all cause chronic or intermittent diarrhea. See your doctor for an accurate diagnosis and treatment.
  • Stress or anxiety. Worrying or feeling under pressure can impact your digestion and lead to loose stools. Managing stress through exercise, meditation, or counseling may help.
The most important thing is to stay hydrated when you have diarrhea. Drink plenty of water or oral rehydration solutions like Pedialyte to avoid dehydration. For most cases of acute diarrhea, the problem will resolve on its own in a couple of days. See a doctor right away if symptoms are severe or last more than 3-4 days. With the proper diagnosis and treatment, chronic diarrhea can also often be managed well.

Diagnosing the Underlying Cause of Diarrhea

If you've been running to the bathroom more often than usual lately, you may have a case of diarrhea. Diarrhea can be caused by infections, food intolerance, medication side effects, and other issues. The good news is, most cases will clear up on their own within a few days. However, it's important to stay hydrated and determine the underlying cause. To diagnose the reason for your diarrhea, think about any recent changes in your diet or medication regimen. Common culprits include eating spoiled or contaminated food, taking antibiotics, or a stomach virus. You'll also want to take note of any other symptoms like nausea, cramps, or fever. If your diarrhea is severe or lasts more than a couple of days, see your doctor. They may order blood tests, stool tests, or other procedures to check for infections and other possible causes. Some of the most likely diagnoses for acute diarrhea include: •Viral gastroenteritis (stomach flu): Spread through contact with infected people or surfaces. Usually lasts 1-2 days. •Bacterial infection: From food poisoning or contaminated water. May last 3-4 days. Requires antibiotics for treatment. •Food intolerance or allergy: A reaction to something you ate. Symptoms appear quickly after eating the trigger food. •Medication side effect: Some drugs can irritate your stomach or intestines. Talk to your doctor about alternative options or dosages. The key is identifying the cause so you can get the appropriate treatment, whether it's staying home to rest, taking medication, or making diet changes. With the right diagnosis and care, your diarrhea should clear up and your digestive system will be back to normal before you know it.

Preventing Dehydration From Diarrhea

To prevent dehydration from diarrhea, you need to make replacing lost fluids a top priority. Drink plenty of oral rehydration solutions like Pedialyte, CeraLyte and oral rehydration salts (ORS) to restore electrolyte balance.

Stay Hydrated

Drink small sips of fluid frequently, even if you don't feel thirsty. Aim for drinking about a cup of oral rehydration solution every 30-60 minutes. Broths, soups, and popsicles also count towards your fluid intake. The key is taking in more fluid than you're losing from diarrhea and vomiting. Watch for signs of dehydration like dizziness, dark urine, and dry mouth. If symptoms worsen or last more than a few days, see your doctor right away.

Replace Electrolytes

In addition to water, diarrhea causes you to lose important electrolytes like sodium and potassium. Oral rehydration solutions and broths contain the right balance of electrolytes and sugar to help you recover. You can also try coconut water, ripe bananas, potatoes, avocados and yogurt or kefir. Avoid caffeine, alcohol and citrus juices which can further dehydrate you.

Ease Digestion

While recovering from diarrhea, stick to bland, easy-to-digest foods. Good options include rice, bananas, oatmeal, boiled potatoes, toast, and crackers. Avoid fatty, spicy, highly seasoned and sugary foods. Give your digestive system time to heal before returning to your normal diet. Probiotics or yogurt with live active cultures can also help boost good bacteria in your gut. Resting as much as possible allows your body to focus on rehydrating and recovering. If your symptoms are severe or don't start to improve within a couple of days, you may need IV fluids or hospitalization. See your doctor right away for bloody diarrhea, high fever, or signs of dehydration in young children and infants. Careful fluid management and allowing your digestive system to rest will help you overcome diarrhea and prevent dangerous dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.

Treating Diarrhea With OTC Medications

If over-the-counter medications aren't helping improve your diarrhea after a couple of days, it's time to try some other options to get relief from your symptoms. Here are a few things you can try:

Anti-diarrheal medications

Look for loperamide (Imodium A-D), diphenoxylate (Lomotil), or atropine/diphenoxylate (Lomotil A-D). These medications work by slowing the movement in the intestines to reduce diarrhea. Follow the directions on the packaging to determine the proper dosage for your symptoms. These medications come in liquid and tablet forms.

Bismuth subsalicylate

Products like Pepto-Bismol and Kaopectate contain bismuth subsalicylate, which works as an antidiarrheal agent. It coats the irritated lining of the intestines. It comes as a liquid or chewable tablet. Be sure to follow the directions for the proper dosage. Bismuth subsalicylate may cause temporary staining of the tongue and stools.

Probiotics

Take an over-the-counter probiotic supplement, like Florastor or Culturelle, to help restore balance to the good bacteria in your gut. Probiotics introduce live strains of bacteria similar to the natural bacteria in your intestines. They may help reduce diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramps. Follow the dosage directions on the product for the best results.

Rehydration solutions

In addition to the above treatments, be sure to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water or rehydration solutions like Pedialyte, Enfamil Enfalyte or Gatorade G2. These provide hydration along with important electrolytes like sodium and potassium that are lost due to frequent stools and fluid loss. Drink at least one glass after each loose stool to ward off dehydration. If your diarrhea lasts more than a couple of days, you have severe pain or dehydration, or see blood in the stools, consult your doctor. They can determine if any prescription medication or IV fluids are needed to help you recover.

When to See a Doctor for Severe or Persistent Diarrhea

If your diarrhea lasts more than a couple of days, it's time to call your doctor. Severe or persistent diarrhea can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance, which requires medical attention. See your doctor right away if:
  • You experience signs of dehydration like increased thirst, dry mouth, dizziness or lightheadedness. Dehydration is especially dangerous for young children and the elderly.
  • You have severe abdominal pain or cramping that doesn't go away.
  • You have a high fever (over 101.5°F or 38.6°C) or chills.
  • There is blood or pus in your stool. This can indicate an infection and requires antibiotics.
  • You have recently traveled outside the country. You may have picked up a parasite or other infection that needs treatment.
  • An infant has diarrhea. Infants are especially prone to dehydration and may need hospitalization and IV fluids.
  • You have a weakened immune system from a medical condition or treatment like chemotherapy. Even a minor illness can become serious quickly.
  • Home treatments like oral rehydration solutions, the BRAT diet, probiotics or over-the-counter medications haven't helped improve your symptoms after a couple of days. You may need prescription medication.
  • You experience signs of an electrolyte imbalance like muscle cramps, a fast or irregular heartbeat, confusion or restlessness. Electrolyte levels can get dangerously low with prolonged diarrhea and vomiting.
Don't hesitate to call your doctor if you have any concerns about the severity or duration of your diarrhea. They can evaluate your symptoms, order any necessary tests, and determine the appropriate treatment to help you recover and prevent complications. With prompt medical care, most cases of acute diarrhea will clear up within a few days. But when left untreated, the risks to your health can quickly become severe.

Conclusion

So there you have it, the common causes and treatments for diarrhea to be aware of. The key things to remember are to stay hydrated, get extra rest, and stick to a bland diet as your body recovers. For most cases of diarrhea, these self-care steps are enough for you to feel better within a couple of days. If your symptoms worsen or last more than a few days, don't hesitate to consult your doctor. They may prescribe oral rehydration solutions or antibiotics if an infection is to blame. The good news is diarrhea is usually not serious and will pass. With the right management, you'll be back to your usual self in no time.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Diarrhea, also spelled diarrhoea or diarrhœa, is the condition of having at least three loose, liquid, or watery bowel movements each day. It often lasts for a few days and can result in dehydration due to fluid loss.

item.title: The Fearful Dogs Project: Giving Anxious Dogs a New Lease on Life
item.dc:creator: diggusa
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever come across a dog that seemed perpetually frightened or anxious for no reason? Chances are that poor pup was a victim of improper socialization or even abuse at a young age. The Fearful Dogs Project is dedicated to helping dogs like that. Through customized behavior modification plans, specialized training, and lots of patience and love, they work to build confidence in dogs that have lived their whole lives in fear.

You've probably seen some of their heartwarming before and after stories on social media. Dogs that once cowered in corners or reacted aggressively out of fear are learning to open up to new experiences and trust people. They're going on walks, playing with other dogs, and becoming the happy, socialized pets they were always meant to be. The Fearful Dogs Project believes every dog deserves a chance at life free from fear and anxiety. With the support of donations and volunteers, they're making that belief a reality for dogs in need of a little extra help.

Recognizing Anxiety and Fear in Dogs

Does your dog seem anxious, fearful or shy around new people or in new situations? It can be heartbreaking to see your pup struggling with anxiety and fear. The good news is, there are signs you can look for and steps you can take to help build their confidence. Look for telltale signs of anxiety like excessive barking or whining, pacing, panting, drooling or destructive behavior. Your dog may try to hide or seem clingy. They could seem tense, keep their tail down and avoid direct eye contact. Pay attention to triggers like loud noises, strangers or new places that cause your dog distress. Once you've identified the signs, here are some things you can do: • Stick to a routine. Feed, walk and engage with your dog at the same times every day. Familiarity breeds comfort. • Give them a safe space. Provide an area like a crate or room where your dog can go if they want to feel secure. • Be patient and encouraging. Remain calm and positive, even if your dog is fearful. Reassure them with a gentle tone and praise to help build confidence. • Socialize carefully. Slowly expose your dog to new people and experiences in a gradual way. Give treats, play and praise to help them make positive associations. • Consult a vet or trainer. If anxiety is severely impacting your dog's quality of life, professional guidance may help. Medication or behavioral techniques can be very effective for anxious dogs. With time and consistency, many fearful dogs become more comfortable and confident. Helping an anxious dog overcome their fears and learning to feel secure is an extremely rewarding experience for any dog owner. The key is providing what they need - safety, patience, love and understanding.

The Fearful Dogs Project: How It Started

The Fearful Dogs Project started in 2008 with one goal: to help anxious shelter dogs find loving homes. Sara McMillen founded the nonprofit after realizing fearful dogs were often euthanized simply due to a lack of training and socialization. Sara began by organizing outings to local shelters where volunteers would take fearful dogs for walks, give them treats and belly rubs, and help get them accustomed to new sights and sounds in a gradual, positive way. The results were life-changing. Dogs that were once terrified of human contact started to come out of their shells, gaining confidence through consistent kindness and patience.

How It Works

The Fearful Dogs Project partners with animal shelters and rescue groups to identify dogs that need extra help. Volunteers then provide behavioral training and socialization through:
  1. Weekly shelter visits: Walking, playing with and grooming fearful dogs to help socialize them in a shelter environment.
  2. Foster care: Placing dogs in temporary homes to give them a break from the shelter and focused, individualized attention. Foster parents help socialize dogs and address any behavioral issues before they're adopted.
  3. Adoption support: Helping new owners properly introduce their fearful dog to their home and family, and providing ongoing training advice and resources.
The project has helped over 2,000 fearful dogs get adopted into forever homes. By giving these anxious animals the time, attention and affection they need, The Fearful Dogs Project is saving lives and spreading awareness about the rewards of rescuing a fearful dog.

Rehabilitating Fearful Dogs Through Positive Reinforcement Training

The Fearful Dogs Project uses positive reinforcement training to help rehabilitate anxious and fearful dogs. This humane, reward-based approach helps build dogs’ confidence and changes their negative associations into positive ones. \n\n### Counterconditioning Fearful Behaviors The goal is to countercondition fearful behaviors by repeatedly exposing dogs to the things that frighten them in a controlled setting. This is done at the dog’s own pace so they remain comfortable. Dogs are given high-value treats, play, praise or other rewards in the presence of the scary stimulus. Over multiple short sessions, the dogs learn to associate the once-fearful thing with positive rewards. For example, a dog fearful of strangers may be slowly introduced to new people who gently toss treats to them. A dog afraid of loud noises may listen to recordings of those sounds at a volume they can handle while receiving rewards. The volume is gradually increased over sessions as the dog becomes desensitized. \n\n### Building Confidence Through Training Simple commands and tricks are taught using positive reinforcement techniques like clicker training. This helps build the dogs’ confidence in their ability to understand what is being asked of them. It also strengthens the bond of trust between the dogs and their trainers or owners. Some of the commands and tricks commonly used include:
  • Sit
  • Stay
  • Come
  • Leave it
  • Look at me
  • Spin
  • Paw
When dogs are able to reliably respond to these cues, more complex behaviors can be shaped. The key is keeping training sessions short, fun and rewarding for the dogs. Through counterconditioning and positive reinforcement training, fearful dogs can become more confident and comfortable engaging with the world around them. While it requires time and patience, the long term rewards of rehabilitating an anxious dog and improving their quality of life are well worth the effort. The Fearful Dogs Project has helped many dogs overcome their fears and find their forever homes.

Success Stories: Timid Dogs Transformed

The Fearful Dogs Project has helped many anxious and timid dogs overcome their fears and find loving homes. Here are a few success stories of dogs that were transformed through the program. \n\n### Max Max, a Siberian Husky, was extremely shy and wary of new people after suffering abuse in his previous home. At first, he would hide in the corner of his kennel and avoid contact with volunteers. After several weeks of positive reinforcement training and socialization, Max started approaching volunteers for treats and belly rubs. He even began excitedly greeting new volunteers. Max was adopted by a loving family with two children he adores. His new family says Max is still cautious at first but quickly warms up to new friends. \n\n### Daisy Daisy, a Labrador Retriever, was fearful of loud noises like trucks, slamming doors, and yelling. She would frantically try to escape any situation where she heard a loud noise. Daisy went through desensitization training, slowly exposing her to recordings of the sounds that frightened her while giving her treats and praise to help her associate the noises with positive experiences. Over time, Daisy became noticeably more relaxed in response to loud noises. Daisy was adopted by a couple in a suburban neighborhood with minimal excess noise to continue supporting her progress. Her new owners say Daisy startles less easily and recovers much faster when she does get scared. \n\n###Buddy Buddy, a Beagle mix, was wary of men and would avoid them by hiding or running away. With the help of male volunteers, Buddy was given treats, belly rubs, playtime, and praise to help him become more comfortable around men. At first, Buddy only felt at ease with the volunteers he knew, but eventually, he became excited to meet new men as well. Buddy was adopted by a single man and loves going on adventures with his new dad. His owner says Buddy is still most eager to greet women, but no longer avoids contact with men and is always excited to see his new favorite guy come home each day. The Fearful Dogs Project proves that with patience, love, and the right training, even the most anxious dogs can overcome their fears and find their perfect families. The transformations of Max, Daisy, Buddy, and many others are a testament to the power of positive reinforcement and second chances.

How You Can Help Anxious Dogs in Your Community

There are several ways you can help support anxious and fearful dogs in your local community.

Donate to Rescues and Shelters

Fearful dogs often end up in shelters and rescues, as their anxiety can make them challenging to care for. Donate money, food, toys or your time to organizations that take in anxious dogs. Your contributions will help ensure these dogs get the care, training and rehabilitation they need to find their forever homes.

Foster a Fearful Dog

By fostering an anxious dog, you’re giving them a temporary place to call home while helping to socialize and train them. Work with the rescue or shelter to continue the dog’s rehabilitation plan. With patience and consistency, you can help build their confidence and prepare them for adoption. If you fall in love, you’ll have the first opportunity to adopt!

Volunteer Your Skills

If you have experience with training, behavioral modification or veterinary care, volunteer your skills with local rescues and shelters. Help evaluate new dogs, assist in creating customized treatment plans, and work hands-on with fearful dogs. Your expertise can make a real difference in these dogs’ lives.

Educate Your Community

Spread awareness about fearful dogs in your neighborhood. Educate people about anxiety in dogs, their needs and how they can help. Talk to local vet clinics, pet stores, groomers and dog walkers about recognizing signs of anxiety or fear in the dogs they see. The more people understand fearful dogs, the more these dogs will be helped.

Adopt, Not Shop

When looking to add a new canine companion to your family, adopt from a shelter or rescue instead of buying from a breeder. Give an anxious dog a loving home and the chance to live their best life as your pet. With time and training, even the most fearful dogs can become confident, devoted family members. Adopting a fearful dog in need is one of the most rewarding ways you can help.

Conclusion

So there you have it, the inspiring story of the Fearful Dogs Project and how these special dogs overcame their fears and found their forever homes. Maybe you know of an anxious dog in need of help or are interested in adopting one yourself. Now you see that with patience, love, and the right training approach, even the most fearful dogs can become confident, happy companions. Who knows, maybe there's a fearful dog out there who needs you as much as you need them. Opening your heart and home to an animal in need is one of the most rewarding things you can do. If these stories have inspired you, spread the word about the Fearful Dogs Project and consider making a donation to help them continue their life-changing work. Together, we can give many

item.title: Top Vet's Desperate Plea: Stop Feeding This Meat to Your Dogs Immediately
item.dc:creator: diggusa
item.content:encoded:
Have you been slowly poisoning your best friend? That question may seem alarmist, but according to one of the nation's top veterinarians, that's exactly what could be happening if you're feeding certain types of meat to your dogs.You want the best for your furry family member, so you carefully choose a high-quality dog food and maybe supplement it with tasty treats and table scraps. But some of the most common meats we feed our dogs could be damaging their health over time in ways you'd never suspect.In an exclusive interview, Dr. Erin Moore reveals why you need to stop feeding one particular meat immediately and switch to healthier, safer alternatives. The effects may not show up right away, but over months and years this meat could be shaving years off your dog's life. If you care about your dog, you'll want to make a change as soon as you learn the truth. Think of it this way: every extra day you feed them this meat is a day you may be stealing from the end of their life. Read on to find out why you need to stop feeding this meat to your dog right now.

Dog Food Ingredient Linked to Disease: A Vet's Warning

As a veterinarian for over 20 years, I have an important warning for dog owners: stop feeding your dog chicken immediately. I know chicken is a staple in many dog food brands and a popular treat, but the risks to your dog's health are just too great. Chicken meat and especially chicken byproducts are cheap fillers used in many popular dog food brands. They seem harmless enough, but chickens these days are bred to grow so quickly that they often suffer from health issues. These issues then get passed on to your dog through the chicken meat and byproducts in their food. The biggest threat is a bacteria called salmonella. Salmonella contamination is rampant in chicken farms and processing plants. While the cooking process may kill the bacteria in chicken for humans, the same is not true for the chicken meal, byproducts and treats fed to dogs. This exposure to salmonella over time can make your dog extremely sick with symptoms like:
  • Vomiting and diarrhea
  • Loss of appetite
  • Fever
  • Lethargy
In severe cases, salmonella poisoning can even be fatal to dogs. I have seen far too many dogs become severely ill or even die from health issues linked to contaminated chicken products in their food and treats. As a vet, I am pleading with dog owners: stop feeding your dog chicken meat, chicken byproducts and chicken-based treats immediately. Your dog's life depends on it. There are many high-quality, natural dog food brands that do not contain any chicken products. Making the switch could add years to your dog's life. Isn't your faithful companion's health worth changing their diet? Do the right thing - stop feeding the chicken and choose a diet with quality, natural ingredients. You will be glad you did.

Safer, Healthier Alternatives: What You Should Feed Your Dog Instead

The best thing you can do for your dog's health is to stop feeding them commercial dog food made with rendered meat byproducts. These meat leftovers—things like intestines, udders, and other unsavory animal parts—are often contaminated with hormones, chemicals, and bacteria. Not to mention, they're barely even meat and lack nutrients. Instead, you should switch your dog to a diet of whole, human-grade meats, grains, and veggies. Homemade dog food, dehydrated dog food, and high-quality kibble made from recognizable ingredients are all safer, healthier options. For homemade dog food, consult with your vet for recipes to ensure it's balanced. In general, choose a lean protein like chicken, turkey, or fish as the main ingredient. Add digestible grains like oatmeal or quinoa, and vegetables such as sweet potatoes, green beans, and carrots. Supplement with essential fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals. Dehydrated dog food, like Honest Kitchen, is just as nutritious but more convenient. It's made from meat and veggies that have been gently dehydrated to preserve nutrients, then packaged into a powder you simply add water to. High-quality kibble, like Blue Buffalo Wilderness, Nutro Wholesome Essentials or Wellness CORE, are made from premium, whole ingredients with meat like deboned chicken, turkey or salmon as the first ingredient. They're free from fillers, byproducts and artificial additives. Any of these options will provide your dog with high-quality protein, healthy grains, and natural nutrition. Best of all, you'll have peace of mind knowing exactly what your best friend is eating. Their improved health, energy, and vitality will make the switch well worth it.

FAQs: Answering Your Questions About This Urgent Issue

You probably have a lot of questions about this urgent issue. Here are some of the most frequently asked questions we receive:

Is this meat safe for humans to eat?

While this meat may be safe for human consumption in moderation, it can be dangerous when fed as a dog's main diet. This is because dogs have different nutritional requirements than humans. They need certain amino acids, fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals in different amounts. This meat lacks some of these key nutrients for dogs and is too high in others.

If this meat isn't good for dogs, why do some pet food companies use it?

Some pet food companies use this meat as a cheap filler to bulk up their dog food without spending a lot on high-quality, nutritious ingredients. They rely on marketing and additives to make the food seem appealing. But many vets agree this meat should not be a primary ingredient in dog food.

Are there any signs my dog may have a problem from eating this meat?

Some signs your dog may have a nutritional deficiency or imbalance from eating this meat include: • Dry, flaky skin and dull coat: Lack of fatty acids and certain vitamins. • Constantly hungry: Lack of protein and amino acids. • Hyperactivity or restlessness: Too much protein and certain additives. • Diarrhea or soft stools: Difficulty digesting this meat and certain additives. • Weight gain or loss: Imbalance of nutrients, especially protein and fat. • Lethargy or lack of energy: Lack of certain minerals and vitamins. • Behavioral changes: Nutritional deficiencies can impact a dog's mood and behavior. • Immune system issues: Lack of certain nutrients can make dogs more prone to illness. The best way to avoid these issues is to not feed your dog a diet high in this questionable meat. Check with your vet for recommendations on high-quality dog food brands and how to transition your dog to a more balanced, nutritious diet. Your dog's long term health depends on it!

Conclusion

So there you have it, straight from the vet's mouth. Chicken jerky treats, especially those imported from China, could be poisoning your dog. The risks are real, and the impacts can be devastating. Why gamble with your best friend's health and happiness? Do what's right and stop feeding these suspicious treats immediately. Your dog depends on you to keep them safe and healthy. Protect them now before it's too late. Toss out those chicken jerky treats and get your pup some all-natural, homemade treats instead. They'll thank you for it, and so will your vet. The life you save could be your faithful compani
